text: Welcome everyone to today's talk about
the Unreal animation framework, our next
generation animation system for UEIE,
UEFn and the open metaverse. My name is
Nicholas Fchett and I am a programmer at
Epic Games.
Before we start, a quick disclaimer that
the technology shown in the Witcher 4
Unreal Engine 5 tech demo is under
active development and will continue to
evolve in the future.
To get us started, here is a quick video
of some of the animation highlights from
yesterday's demo.
Hallelujah.
[music]
>> [music]
>> Nice.
To better understand where we are going
with the Unreal animation framework,
it's worth first taking a step back to
see where we come from and where we are
today.
Animation blueprints are 11 years old
today. And at the time that we were
building it, uh, we had been building
games with Unreal Engine 3 for some
time, uh, using Unreal script and simple
blendries.
A typical multiplayer match at the time
would have had around 10 players
primarily using capsule-driven motion.
And the hardware of that era was slowly
emerging with more cores with where we
you could typically find two to six
threads.
And so it was in that landscape that
animation blueprints were conceived. And
we wanted to primarily address three
things with it. First, we wanted to
increase expressivity by moving away
from simple blendries towards more
powerful animation graphs.
Second, we wanted to unify around
blueprints which were being developed at
the time for a more integrated workflow
between gameplay and animation.
And third, we wanted to push as much of
the animation workload onto the worker
threads as we could.
And this has proven to be quite
successful over the years. And today, in
a typical battle royale match, you can
find a 100 players using a lot a mix of
capsule-driven motion and root motion
from the Nintendo Switch all the way to
the high-end consoles.
We use animation blueprints extensively
for all of this and the hardware trends
have continued in the previous direction
and today we find 8 to 16 threads on
common hardware.
We've also released the Unreal editor
for Fortnite not too long ago, making
game development much more accessible to
developers, allowing for a ton of new
niche and fun game experiences to be
created within the Fortnite ecosystem.
And as we look ahead, we have much
broader ambitions. We envision an open
metaverse where you might have a
thousand plus players within a single
game experience
powered by multiple servers and perhaps
hundreds of threads using the Unreal
animation framework.
The hardware trends have continued to
evolve with today's CPUs having more
cores than ever before and we're now
seeing commonly um a mix of slow and
fast cores in the hardware. This makes
this makes it especially challenging to
manage concurrent workloads efficiently
and it is now more important than ever.
Some are these are just some of the
challenges uh that we are facing ahead.
Let us now focus
on some of the unique specifics in the
Witcher 4 tech demo.
A storydriven world like this is rich
and full of life. NPCs walk about in the
environment. They interact with it. They
interact with one another as well as
with the player. This requires careful
orchestration with gameplay to ensure
contact point fidelity is maintained and
so the execution order is very
important.
Root motion is also desired for the
higher fidelity that we can get and with
it it brings the need for stitching and
warping as we enter and exit contextual
interactions as well as cinematics.
And when the story calls for it, NPCs
can congregate together in a small area
like this.
This is the market scene from the demo.
And here we have over 300 NPCs.
These are not particle system. They are
not GPU vertex animated. They are not
simple crowd actors. Each and every one
of these is a fullyfledged NPC with all
of the bells and whistles that you might
expect. They have slope warping using
control rig. They have look at IK using
control rig. They are motion matching
etc.
All of this is of course running at 60
frames per second on a standard
PlayStation 5.
Root motion in a scene like this is
especially challenging from a
performance point for two reasons.
First, today with animation blueprints,
when you rely on root motion,
animation evaluation is constrained to
the game tread, severely limiting our
ability to reach this kind of scale.
Second, not only do we have to animate
each and every NPC within the view, but
even NPCs not on screen or oluded still
need to continue updating for us to be
able to extract the root motion
and move them about the world.
And so to better adapt to this changing
world and face these challenges head-on,
our answer is the Unreal animation
framework
from the ground up. It has been designed
for high performance. We had a mantra
going into this that you should pay only
for the features that you use. And this
has been our guiding principle
throughout development.
We've greatly minimized game tread
interactions, allowing for far greater
concurrency than before. And progress
continues with our goal to ultimately
remove all game tread interactions.
We've also greatly improved how we
leverage the CPU cache. This
supercharges the single threaded
performance which is as important as
ever whether you run on a small mobile
device or on a single core cloud server.
Today when a graph like this with
animation blueprint is too slow to
execute
it is common to manually convert it into
native C++ through a process that we
call nativization.
Thanks to our efforts on the performance
front, this is now obsolete and no
longer necessary,
allowing artists to remain fully in
control of assets from conception all
the way to final release.
Root Motion no longer has any
performance restriction. It is a first
class citizen and it works regardless of
its source. Whether it comes from
capsule-driven motion, source animation
data or sequencer,
it will flow through the graph like any
other attribute, allowing you to warp it
and blend it however you choose.
We also continue to put a lot of effort
into ensuring that you can create small
and reusable assets
to help reduce contention in source
control as your projects grow in scale
and complexity.
We will be introducing
skeleton families, loosening the
coupling with skeletons, allowing you to
reason about them at a higher
abstraction level. For example,
reasoning about the upper body, lower
body, facial curves, and so on. And the
runtime will figure out the specifics of
what that means for the particular
character that the graph is evaluating
on.
This will allow for easier asset reuse
such as blend profiles while still
allowing for asset specific overrides
when required.
We are also introducing traitbased
animation nodes.
These are fully datadriven. You
aggregate traits in a stack similar to
how mass traits are used or entity
component systems. And it allows you to
create bespoke animation nodes where you
need them. And this is really the
embodiment of the pay for what you use
mantra. If you have a sequence player
that does not need to synchronize in a
group, for example, there is zero memory
overhead, zero CPU overhead for that
feature on that node. It is never
checked at runtime. It isn't there. It
is free.
We've also continued and greatly
improved gameplay integration,
giving you more flexibility in how
things execute in relation to one
another. And similar to animation
blueprints, we have threads safe
variables for input into the system as
well as a threads safe eventbased system
for inputs and outputs.
All of this comes together under a
unified pipeline because first and
foremost, this is a tactical evolution
of our existing framework. Our goal is
to be able to reuse as many of the
assets that you have today where
possible such as animation sequences,
blend spaces, motion matching databases
and so on.
We are bringing control rig and state
tree closer together with the rest of
the animation runtime as first class
citizens.
This will come with a consistent usering
experience allowing you to move from one
to the other in a seamless manner
allowing you to compose them in new
powerful ways.
We've also augmented Rewind Debugger
with all the new features of the Unreal
animation framework, giving you
unprecedented insights into everything
that goes on within the animation
runtime. from how motion matching
selects its animation, how animations
are synchronizing together within a sync
group to how they blend together and
layer to produce a final pose. We've
also greatly improved capture and replay
performance to be able to work at the
sorts of scale that you've seen.
Now, on to the good stuff. On the right
here, you have an image of a capture I
took a few weeks ago from a development
build.
This is in the market where there are
over 300 NPCs running at 60 frames per

out that even NPCs that are offscreen
are fully animating, although at the
lowest level of detail.
In here, we animate over 45,000 bones
each frame, and this is split over 800
skeletal meshes. NPCs are built from
multiple parts, similar to what you
would do today with animation blueprints
using copy pose uh from mesh.
The total animation cost is around 52
milliseconds per frame split over 12
worker treads.
As you would expect, NPCs have various
levels of details for both visuals and
animation.
And our cheapest tier runs in about 0.06
milliseconds to 0.12 milliseconds each,
while the highest tier with cloth and
metahuman facial animation takes about
1.6 milliseconds.
We have a budget system to allocate
these as you move about the world.
And you can see here on the right that
the CPU is still idle for a great great
amount of time.
Last but not least, this slide here

Um this is a smoothed graph. At the top
you'll see the smooth blue line there
across at 16.6 milliseconds
followed by the yellow line beneath it
which is the GPU time showing that we

visuals that we've seen.
Just beneath it in the pale blue, you
see the game tread time peaking at
around 12 to 13 milliseconds there uh
while smooed with the orange and green
lines below being the two render
threads.
And from this you can see that despite
everything we've thrown at the screen,
there still remains ample room for
gameplay to bring the world alive.

Now let's see how the motion matching

With the added flexibilities of UAF, we
